Project Description  The Third Education Development Project (the Project) will build on the 
achievements of the Education Sector Development Program (ESDP) 
and Second Education Development Project (SEDP) and will assist the 
Government  in  improving  the  quality  and  relevance  of  primary, 
secondary,  and  vocational  education.  The  Project  has  three 
components:  (i)  developing  a  national  curriculum  framework  and 
aligned  education  standards,  (ii)  improving  teaching  and  learning 
environments in primary and secondary schools, and (iii) promoting 
demand-driven vocational education for the youth.  
   
Rationale  Key issues in the current Mongolian education system are (i) poor 
quality  and  relevance  of  the  current  curriculum  for  primary  and 
secondary education, (ii) inadequate teaching qualifications and skills, 
(iii)  lack  of  consistent  education  standards,  (iv)  weak  learning  and 
teaching  environments  in  schools,  and  (v)  supply-driven  irrelevant 
vocational education for youth. The Government has decided to extend 
the education system from the current 10-year system to a 12-year 
system  in  2008,  which  will  align  Mongolia’s  education  system  with 
international standards. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will assist 
the Government in the implementation of this policy, which will require 
comprehensive reform of the curriculum framework, establishing new 
education standards, streamlining the current teacher in-service training 
system, and developing a national teacher accreditation system.  
 
The  limited  capacity  and  poor  condition  of  school  facilities—which 
continue to deteriorate—are major constraints to increasing enrolment 
and retention, and improving the quality of education services. This has 
been particularly acute in rural areas where budget funds for preventive 
maintenance  and  technical  resources  for  rehabilitation  are  scarce. 
Building construction and technology are inefficient in terms of use of 
materials, structural capacity, and energy performance.

iv   
  The Ministry of Education, Culture and Science (MECS) is the sole 
public sector provider of vocational and technical education (VTE) for 
the youth. Currently, vocational education programs are based on the 
former  Soviet  system,  which  is  neither  responsive  to  labor  market 
demands  nor  cost-effective.  Graduates  have  difficulty  finding  jobs 
because they lack employable skills. School facilities have deteriorated, 
adequate  training  equipment  is  lacking  or  outdated,  and  the 
pedagogical and technical skills and knowledge of many teachers are 
outdated. With the introduction of the 12-year school system, the VTE 
system  will  need  to  be  adjusted  to  the  new  national  curriculum 
framework. 
   
ADB’s  assistance  to  the  education  sector  in  Mongolia  has  evolved 
since the early 1990s to support the Government in strengthening the 
education  system  step-by-step.  ESDP  was  approved  in  1996  and 
included a program loan to support fundamental policy reforms in the 
organization,  management,  staffing,  and  financing  of  the  education 
sector; and a project loan to support initial investments. SEDP was 
approved in 2002 and builds on the initial reform framework established 
by  ESDP,  with  a  focus  on  school  and  kindergarten  rehabilitation, 
provision  of  learning  materials,  and  limited  support  in  curriculum 
development and teacher training. The Project focuses on two major 
features which have not been addressed by previous interventions: (i) a 
comprehensive  curriculum  reform,  in  support  of  the  Government’s 
decision to extend the schooling period by 2 years; and (ii) reforming 
the  current  VTE  system,  which  is  a  development  priority  of  the 
Government to enhance employment and income-earning opportunities 
and  promote  economic  growth.  The  Project  contributes  to  two 
Millennium  Development  Goals:  (i)  achieving  universal  primary 
education,  and  (ii)  eliminating  gender  disparity  in  primary  and 
secondary education. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The impact of the Project will be improved employability and income-
earning  opportunities  of  graduates  from  secondary  and  vocational 
education. The outcome of the Project will be enhanced and more 
equitable access to—and improved quality and relevance of—primary, 
secondary, and vocational education. 
   
Cost Estimates  The total project cost is estimated at $16.38 million equivalent. The 
foreign exchange cost is estimated at $3.83 million (24% of the total 
cost)  and  the  local  currency  cost  is  estimated  at  $12.55  million 
equivalent (76% of the total cost).

Project Benefits and  Direct beneficiaries of the Project will include all students enrolled in 
Beneficiaries  primary and secondary schools. Nationwide, about 560,000 students—
including about 201,000 students from poor families—will benefit from 
improved curriculum, well-defined education standards, and enhanced 
assessment systems. About 31,000 students and 1,200 teachers will 
benefit from improved school and dormitory facilities in 45 schools to be

  About 21,900 students of vocational education institutions will benefit

benefit  from  rehabilitated  facilities  and  modern  training  equipment. 
Industries and services will benefit from improvements in relevance and 
quality of VTE. Graduates of VTE institutions entering the labor force 
will possess knowledge and skills in line with industry requirements, 
contribute to higher labor productivity, and increase economic growth. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Successful implementation of the Project rests on the assumption that 
the Government will (i) maintain the high level of budget allocation for 
the education sector; (ii) be committed to improve donor coordination to 
strengthen the effectiveness and efficiency of the delivery of education 
services; (iii) maintain its commitment to carry out education reforms, 
including national curriculum reform; (iv) provide adequate budget to 
provide in-service training for all teachers employed by the system; and 
(v)  reform  and  rationalize  the  current  VTE  system.  To  achieve  its 
impact, the Project assumes that further steady economic growth will 
create new job opportunities. 
 
The managerial and technical capacity of MECS is limited and might 
affect the smooth implementation of the extension of the school system 
to  a  12-year  system  and  the  introduction  of  the  new  curriculum 
framework nationwide. The  risks  will  be mitigated through training and

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
Mongolia  for  the  Third  Education  Development  Project.  The  report  also  describes  proposed 
technical assistance (TA) for Development of a Sector Wide Approach in Education, and if the 
Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will 
approve the TA. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  In 2002, the Government requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide TA to 
assist the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science (MECS) to prepare the Third Education 
Development Project (the Project)1 as a follow-up to the ongoing Second Education Development 
Project (SEDP)2 and the Education Sector Development Program (ESDP)3 that was successfully 
completed in 2002. The Government considers improving the quality of the education system, 
enhancing access to basic education services, and promoting demand-driven vocational education 
to be key instruments to alleviate poverty, accelerate economic growth, and reduce disparities in 
the  development  process—particularly  between  rural  and  urban  areas.  In  accordance  with 
Government’s  development  strategy,  the  Project  is  included  in  ADB’s  Country  Strategy  and 
Program Update 2005–2006 and Country Strategy and Program (CSP) 2006–2008. 4 The project 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Socioeconomic Context 
 
3.  After 14 years of economic transition, Mongolia stands out as a good performer among 
transition economies. Profound economic reform has led to the successful implementation of the 
pillars of a market economy and, at present, substantive macroeconomic stabilization has been 
achieved. However, gross domestic product (GDP) per capita ($602 in 2004) has not yet reached 
pre-transition levels and poverty has emerged as an unwelcome side effect of the transition. 
Poverty spread on a large scale in the 1990s as a consequence of the structural transformation of 
the economy. Following the collapse of the socialist institutions, a range of services deteriorated, 
including health care, education, transportation, water supply, and sanitation. Poverty remains 
persistent in both rural and urban Mongolia and 36% of the population live below the national 
poverty line ($0.75 a day). Continued growth is helping to lift living standards but the benefits are 
not distributed equally among the population, as revealed by income inequality and unchanged 
poverty incidence. Rural poverty is significantly higher than urban poverty, with Western Mongolia 
standing out as the most seriously affected region. Sectoral composition of GDP has changed, with 
industry and services expanding fast while agriculture has declined. This has led to a significant 
migration  flow  from  the  countryside  to  the  major  urban  centers,  which  has  caused  major 
imbalances in educational service provision. A total of 57.4% of the population currently lives in 
urban centers.

4.  Mongolia has a relatively young, economically active population. Of the total population of 
about 2.5 million, 38% are below the age of 16, and 55% are of working age. The sharp fall in 
average income that marked the first years of the transition triggered a drop in birth rate and the 
population’s growth rate declined from 2.7% in 1989 to 0.8% in 2004. 
 
5.  High  unemployment  (14.2%)  and  underemployment  caused  by  a  mismatch  between 
available skills and labor market needs is one of the major causes of poverty. The service sector is 
the main source of employment in Mongolia, followed by agriculture and industry. However, the 
pattern is completely different in urban and rural areas. While services account for 75% of the 
employed in urban centers, they employ only 5% of the rural labor force, which is mainly engaged 
in livestock and farming activities. The lack of relevant knowledge and skills among poor migrants 
restricts their earning opportunities to intermittent low-wage employment in the informal sector and 
is a major cause of poverty among this group. The recent Household Income and Expenditure 
Survey and Living Standards Measurement Survey5 found that the poor have lower education 
attainments than the nonpoor in general; and lack the managerial, professional, or technological 
skills required in burgeoning industries. The divide is particularly evident in urban areas where only 
14% of the poor possess skills in demand, compared with 38% of the nonpoor.  
 
6.  Mongolia’s  experience  suggests  that  economic  growth  does  not  translate  into  poverty 
reduction immediately, given the narrow base of the economy and its vulnerability to external 
shocks. Hence, specific interventions are required to combat poverty. Education is perceived as an 
important vehicle to reduce poverty, upgrade human development, and generate job opportunities. 
Improving the quality and relevance of education—both in urban and rural areas—is essential to 
strengthen  the  country’s  human  capital,  widen  the  range  of  opportunities  for  employment 
generation, and promote competitiveness and private sector development.  
 
2.  Education Sector 
 
7.  Education was one of Mongolia’s main achievements in the socialist era. School and 
dormitory facilities were established in all soums (districts), allowing all children—including those 
from remote nomadic families—to obtain a basic education. Results were impressive. The gross 
enrolment  rate  (GER)  in  primary  and  secondary  education  reached  99%  by  1990.  This  was 
accompanied by high literacy rates which, even in 2004, stood at 97% of the population aged over 
15. With the termination of financial and technical support from the Soviet Union in 1991, the 
quality of and access to education services in Mongolia deteriorated. State education expenditures 
were massively reduced. Without finance for operation and maintenance (O&M) and essential 
repairs,  school  facilities  deteriorated  and  many  were  forced  to  close.  Availability  of  learning 
materials dwindled and teachers’ real salaries eroded distinctly. By 1996, the GER had fallen to 
82% and dropout rates6 had increased. A description of the education sector is in Appendix 2. 
 
8.  Robust  planning  and  investments  by  the  Government—and  major  support  from  ADB, 
Government of Japan, and other development partners over the last 10 years—have reversed this 
decline and resulted in improvements across the education sector, including (i) major policy reform; 
(ii) rationalization of financing, staff, and facilities; and (iii) rehabilitation and upgrading of a large 
number of school facilities and classrooms. In the 2003–2004 school year, the GER increased to

9.  The formal education system in Mongolia consists of kindergarten and preschool (up to 
age 7), primary education (4 years), lower secondary education (4 years), and upper secondary 
education (2 years). From the 2005–2006 school year, the Government extended the structure of

MECS is the central administrative body that formulates national educational policy and sets the 
standards  for  each  level  of  formal  education.  MECS  also  administers  general  provisions  on

and is responsible for the accreditation of higher education institutions. 
 
10.  MECS is the sole public sector provider of vocational and technical education (VTE) for 
youth. Vocational and technical training and retraining for adults is offered by institutions under the 
Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare (MLSW), other line ministries, and the private sector. MECS 
administers a total of 42 VTE institutions. There are 22 vocational education and training centers 
(VETCs) and vocational training and production centers (VTPCs), which offer a 2.5-year combined 
professional and general education, leading to a professional certificate and a secondary education 
certificate. The entry level for VTPCs/VETCs is grade 8. The curriculum in VTPCs/VETCs retains 
large elements of the pre-transitional system. MECS also administers 14 branch schools (attached 
to  higher  education  institutions)  and  6  technical  colleges,  which  provide  advanced  technical 
education  for  higher-level  skills  development,  leading  to  a  professional  diploma  or  bachelors 
degree. In 2004–2005, 21,911 students were enrolled in VETCs, VTPCs, and branch schools. 
 
11.  Mongolia’s education expenditure is among the highest of the transition countries at 7.3% 
of GDP or 18.5% of the total national budget in 2004. Expenditure on primary and secondary 
education  is  highest  among  the  subsectors,  at  48%  of  total  education  expenditure,  with 
kindergarten (preschool) education at 17%, VTE at 4%, higher education7 at 19%, and other 
expenditure8 at 12%. Of total expenditure on education in 2004, recurrent expenditure amounted to 
91.3%, capital expenditure 4.5%, and net lending (through the State Education and Training Fund) 
4.2%. 
 
12.  Depending on the location of schools, between 70% and 90% of school budgets are spent 
on personnel and heating costs.9 The Government’s commitment to meet salaries and heating 
costs will continue to absorb most of the annual budget for education. Education financing is 
expected to remain sufficient over the short to medium term to maintain the current status of the 
education  system.10  However,  given  the  high  level  of  investment  needs  in  the  sector,  while 
government  expenditure  is  expected  to  be  sufficient  to  cover  recurrent  expenditure  and 
incremental O&M costs, it is unlikely to be able to accommodate further increases in investment

13.  Despite gains over the past decade, the affordability of education continues to present

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Key Issues and Challenges 
14.  National  Curriculum  Framework  and  Revised  Education  Standards.  The  planned 
introduction of a new 12-year education system will need to be supported by curriculum reform and 
the development of agreed education standards for each subject and grade level. At present, a 
consistent broad curriculum frame linked to educational standards is not in place. The extension of 
the schooling period has not been reflected in recent curriculum revisions. The current education 
curriculum is overloaded with subjects and content requirements, with insufficient emphasis on 
modern learning methodologies, and echoes learning arrangements of the socialist era, which are 
no longer consistent with the need for greater flexibility in subject selection and a student-centered 
teaching environment. MECS has started the process of revising education standards and a set of 
new standards has been published. However, the new education standards have not yet taken into 
account the need to modernize the curriculum framework; and teachers, parents, and textbook 
authors find the standards too complex and difficult to translate into clear student competences. At 
present, student examinations have little transparency due to lack of clear standards. Exams are 
not prepared according to uniform national standards and are not comparable between schools, 
which makes it difficult to monitor quality.  
 
15.  Teachers’ Qualifications. The main constraints on improving educational quality are the 
lack  of  a  (i)  comprehensive  teacher  in-service  training  system,  and  (ii)  national  teacher 
accreditation system. Currently, there is no agreed national teacher accreditation system in place. 
Students graduate from 38 universities and colleges with different levels of education. Training 
programs at these universities and colleges do not follow agreed national standards. School and 
aimag (province) authorities are in charge of teacher recruitment and assessment. However, due 
to the lack of national agreed professional standards and teacher accreditation schemes, the 
knowledge and competence of new teachers vary from school to school.  
 
16.  The teaching techniques and subject knowledge of many teachers are inadequate and 
outdated and need to be upgraded, particularly in rural areas. The shortage of qualified English 
and vocational teachers is largely due to the inability of the education sector to compete with the 
private sector in employing personnel with these skills. Emphasis needs to be placed on improving 
teachers’  working  conditions  and  upgrading  their  qualifications.  Currently,  in-service  teacher 
training is carried out by 22 Education and Culture Departments (ECDs) at aimag level, some 
universities and colleges, and donor supported projects. However, training programs do not follow 
national standards, are not coordinated, and do not include all teachers employed by the system. 
The new national curriculum frame and the extension of the schooling period by 2 years will place 
new demands on teacher’s skills and competencies.

5 
17.  Facilities. A major constraint on increasing enrollment and retention and improving the 
quality  of  education  services  is  the  limited  capacity  of  school  facilities,  which  continues  to 
deteriorate due to inadequate maintenance and investment. This has been particularly acute in 
rural areas, where budget funds for O&M and resources for rehabilitation are scarce. Lack of safe 
water and sanitation pose significant hygiene and health risks, especially for students in dormitory 
facilities. Building construction and technology of schools, which have not yet benefited form 
rehabilitation measures, are based on 30-year old construction standards that are inefficient in 
terms of use of materials, structural capacity, and energy performance. Insulations are poor and 
urban schools’ heating systems are usually linked to a public heating distribution system without 
metering or control of consumption.  
 
18.  Recent large-scale migration from rural to urban areas—in addition to being one of the 
results of declining service provision in rural areas—has caused major imbalances in educational 
service provision and has greatly tested the capacity of schools in areas witnessing high population 
inflows.11 Schools in urban centers have seen demand for services increase substantially, while 
some rural schools are now operating below capacity as a result of outflows from their catchment 
areas. The introduction of a 12-year system in 2008 will cause a significant increase in student 
numbers in the national education system, which will be an additional burden on schools’ capacity. 
The increase in enrollments and lack of additional school space will force about one third of all 
secondary schools to conduct classes in two or even three shifts. MECS has identified 200 out of 
710 schools in urgent need of rehabilitation, which will require donor assistance due to national 
budget constraints. The lack of adequate teaching aids and learning materials is another major 
constraint on applying modern teaching methodologies. In rural schools, in particular, teaching 
equipment for science subjects and up-to-date computer equipment are lacking. Reliance on more 
traditional resources, such as chalkboard and textbooks, in pre-service and in-service training had 
led to teaching being dominated by traditional "chalk and talk" centered learning. 
 
19.  Vocational and technical education has been one of most neglected areas of education 
in Mongolia. The Government enacted legislation to encourage the private sector to become 
involved in VTE and subsequently reduced its role in this subsector. However, only a few private 
training providers and companies are engaged in vocational education and are providing support. 
Currently, there is a serious mismatch between skills supply and labor market demand, which 
impedes further economic growth and leads to lack of sufficiently skilled labor. The economic 
consequences  of  these  deficiencies  are  unemployment,  lagging  competitiveness,  insufficient 
innovation, and low productivity. At present, MECS is the sole public provider of VTE for youth. 
Training programs for youth offered by private training institutions are limited to few sectors in 
urban areas. Students from rural areas are disadvantaged in gaining access to private training and 
children from poor families are unable to afford training fees. A lack of employment opportunities 
and adequate private and public training provisions make it crucial to promote VTE as a means to 
provide employable skills and knowledge to students who do not advance to higher education.   
 
20.  Mongolia’s VTE system is in need of comprehensive reform. The current VTE program—
offering a combined 2.5-year professional and general education based on the former Soviet 
system—is not responsive to labor market demands or cost-effective. Although VTE students 
declined from 11% in 1987 to 4% in 2004 as a proportion of all students in grades 1–10, enrollment 
in VTE institutions increased from 12,177 in 2000 to 21,911 in 2004. Graduates of the combined 
system have difficulty competing with the academic performance of graduates from the general 
secondary education stream, and do not find jobs easily after graduation without further on-the-job-
training due to their lack of employable skills. With the introduction of the 12-year school system,

21.  Training  programs  currently  offered  by  MECS  are  supply-driven  and  have  not  yet

be upgraded. Teachers have no benchmarks to measure their own technical and instructional

national policy on VTE (linking both systems under MECS and MLSW with present and future labor 
market needs) and a recognized national system for skills standards are not in place.  
 
2.  Government Policy 
22.  The Government’s Economic Growth Support and Poverty Reduction Strategy (EGSPRS), 
the National Action Plan, and Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) for education, together 
describe  the  Government’s  development  strategy  in  the  education  sector.  The  Project  will 
contribute to two MDGs: “Achieve universal primary education” and “Eliminate gender disparity in 
primary and secondary education”. The Government considers strengthening the education system 
as an integral part of its (i) economic growth strategy, aimed at steady, private sector-led growth; 
and (ii) social strategy, aimed at improving access of the poor to stable income opportunities and 
improving the quality and accessibility of public services.  
 
23.  The Government’s education policy has been driven by the Education Sector Strategy 
(ESS) (2000–2005) and the Education for All strategic plan. The major focus of the ESS has been 
on improvements in (i) access to, and quality and relevance of, basic education services; and 
(ii) development of qualified and competitive human resources, contributing to raise economic 
growth. Building on the achievements and lessons learned from the ESS (2000–2005), MECS is 
currently developing a new Education Master Plan for 2006–2015 with assistance from ADB. 
 
3.  External Assistance to the Sector 
24.  ADB and the Government of Japan are the major development partners in the education 
sector in Mongolia. ADB has supported the Government’s efforts to strengthen the education 
system since the early 1990s (para 30). The Government of Japan is financing the upgrading of 
primary  and  secondary  schools,  strengthening  teacher  training,  and  providing  support  for 
information and communication technology (ICT) in education. ADB has coordinated with the 
Canadian International Development Agency, whose feasibility study on school construction and 
rehabilitation contributed significantly to the SEDP’s design. The United Nations Children’s Fund 
(UNICEF)  is  active  in preschool, nonformal,  and  primary  education.  The  Danish  International  
Development Assistance agency has supported the development of 40 rural schools. The World 
Bank has financed small-scale renovations of schools under its Poverty Alleviation Program and is 
financing a public expenditure tracking survey in the education sector. Currently, the World Bank is 
preparing  a  Rural  Education  Support  Project  financed  from  an  International  Development 
Association  grant.  Germany  has  provided  support  for  selected  vocational  schools  while  the 
European Union has provided support for higher education. With the exception of assistance 
provided  by  ADB  and  the  Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency  (JICA),  inputs  by  these

7 
agencies have been relatively modest in financial terms. In 2004, the Government submitted a 
proposal to the Millennium Challenge Corporation with a sizeable educational component, which is 
currently under review. An overview of donor funded projects is in Appendix 3. The project design 
has been prepared in close coordination with JICA, World Bank, UNICEF, and Germany [GTZ].  
 
25.  At present, investment in the education sector is fragmented. Externally financed projects 
are largely planned and executed directly between development agencies and the Government, 
limiting coordination and coherence between projects and raising transaction costs. To enhance 
harmonization and coordination, and improve the efficiency of donor assistance, the Government 
and the donor community agreed that the current cooperation mechanism needs to be improved. 
Donor interventions should be fully in accordance with government policies, under government 
leadership. At the initiative of ADB, World Bank, JICA, and UNICEF, the proposal to gradually 
establish a sector wide approach (SWAp) in the education sector emerged, with agreement that 
ADB would take the lead. The proposed SWAp strategy will be underpinned by a partnership-
based approach aimed at enhancing joint donor planning towards direct budget support for the 
national education system. As a first step in that direction, MECS and key donors have formally 
agreed to establish a donor consultative mechanism in education, aimed at enhancing donor 
coordination and harmonization within the framework of the new Master Plan. 
  
4.  Lessons Learned 
26.  The project design takes into consideration experience gained and lessons learned in 
implementing the ESDP, the ongoing SEDP, and the project for Innovating Rural Education in 
Mongolia through ICT (IIREM).12 Through ESDP’s reform program, the education facilities and staff 
of around 120 primary and secondary schools were rationalized and merged into 45 complex 
schools, which contributed to improving the effectiveness of the education system and quality of 
education services. By 2004, 210 schools have been rehabilitated under the ESDP and SEDP, 
which has resulted in stronger student participation in rural areas, decreased dropout rates, and 
improved  teaching  and  learning  environments.  The  Project  will  benefit  from  the  technical 
experience in school rehabilitation, in particular regarding improving heating systems, sanitation, 
and roof repairs. The selection criteria for schools to be rehabilitated under the Project will consider 
indicators to increase participation of poor students in rural areas and students from migrant 
families in urban centers. 
 
27.  SEDP and IIREM have developed strategies for using ICT to bring education content, 
modern pedagogy, and information to schools. Lessons learned from these projects will help to 
develop  a  new  in-service  teacher  training  approach  based  on  ICT  methods.  Further  lessons 
learned relate to the need to ensure that (i) adequate O&M budgets and preventive maintenance of 
rehabilitated school facilities are provided, (ii) necessary infrastructure is in place prior to the 
provision of modern teaching and learning equipment, and (iii) sufficient budgets are in place to 
cover ensuing expenditures for utilizing ICT equipment and facilities efficiently. 
 
28.  A major lesson learned relates to the importance of donor coordination. At present, the level 
of harmonization of donor activities in the education sector is low and MECS manages donor 
funded projects largely on an individual basis. The Project’s strategy aims at achieving improved 
donor harmonization and coordination across the sector. Through an associated TA, the project 
design addresses the need to strengthen MECS’ core technical and management capacity to 
enable the ministry to take a phased approach to establishing a SWAp in education.

5.  ADB’s Sector Strategy 
29.  ADB’s assistance to the education sector in Mongolia has evolved since the early 1990s to 
support the Government in the different stages of reforming and strengthening the education 
system. ESDP was approved in 1996 and included (i) a program loan to support fundamental 
policy reforms in the organization, management, staffing, and financing of the education sector; 
and (ii) a project loan to support initial investments. SEDP was approved in 2002 and builds on the 
initial reform framework established by ESDP, with focus on school and kindergarten rehabilitation, 
provision of learning materials, and limited support in curriculum development and teacher training. 
ESDP was completed in 2002 and rated highly successful in the project completion report.13 The 
implementation progress of SEDP is fully satisfactory. The Project focuses on two major features 
which have not been addressed by previous interventions: (i) a comprehensive curriculum reform 
in support of the Government’s decision to extend the schooling period by 2 years, which will align 
Mongolia’s  education  system  with  international  standards;  and  (ii)  reforming  the  current  VTE 
system, which is a government priority, to promote economic growth. 
 
30.  The focus of the Project is consistent with ADB’s Policy on Education.14 Activities are aimed 
at reducing poverty and providing knowledge and skills essential to meet the needs of a demand-
driven modern economy. ADB’s strategy in the education sector, as outlined in the CSP 2006–
2008, will remain focused on (i) improving access to, and quality of, basic education services; (ii) 
more  efficient  and  effective  education  provision;  (iii)  promoting  demand-driven  vocational 
education; and (iv) more effective donor coordination. The new Education Master Plan 2006–
201515 is considered a key sector output, which will provide a strategic framework to ensure that 
education spending and investment in the sector is evidence-based, informed, and sustainable. 
After supporting the Government in reforming the curriculum framework and adopting a SWAp in 
the education sector, future ADB assistance is expected to focus on providing education services 
to rural and marginal urban populations and further development of private provision of education 
and skills training, as set out in the CSPU 2005–2006.

33.  The Project will assist MECS in developing a new national curriculum framework for the 12-

in-service training system with the objective to improve the quality, relevance, and efficiency of 
primary and secondary education. Four subcomponents will contribute to meet these objectives: 
(i) developing a national 12-year curriculum framework, including the rationalization of subjects for 
basic education; (ii) establishing a mechanism to streamline educational standards, based on the 
new  curriculum  framework,  and  linking  them  to  national  standards  for  teacher  education; 
(iii) establishing a national accreditation system for pre-service teacher training programs and a

in-service teacher training system based on the new standards and national curriculum framework. 
The component will include assistance to develop strategies for textbook preparation, including the

a.  Development of a National Curriculum Framework 
34.  This  subcomponent  will  assist  MECS  in  rationalizing  the  number  of  subjects  in  basic

into key learning areas (KLAs)17 and key learning outcomes. The curriculum framework will be 
student-centered and will include (i) the scope and sequence of student learning for all core 
subjects; (ii) a national curriculum statement; (iii) a national policy for assessment and reporting; 
(iv) teacher guides for preschool, primary, and secondary education; (v) new syllabi and teacher 
guides for integrated subjects;18 (vi) in-service modules to support implementation of the curriculum 
framework; and (vii) implementation guides for school head teachers. Prior to the development of 
the  national  curriculum  framework,  30  teacher  educators  selected  from  MECS,  universities,

standards.  Criteria  to  select  the  teacher  educators  will  be  developed  by  MECS,  with  ADB 
concurrence. Supported by international and domestic consultants, these teacher educators will—
jointly with MECS—develop the new curriculum framework and revise standards and guidelines for 
textbook development. The national curriculum framework will be accompanied by developing 
user-friendly manuals for understanding and using the framework, teaching methods handbooks 
for each of the core subjects, and teacher guidebooks. These manuals and guidebooks will be 
provided to all 21,000 primary and secondary teachers. A further 4,000 sets of materials will be 
prepared for graduates entering the teaching profession during the life of the Project.

The selection criteria will include (i) preparedness to enroll students from poor and/or migrated 
families, (ii) evidence that adequate budget will be provided for O&M of equipment and provision of 
consumables, (iii) confirmation that the new curriculum at institution level is relevant and demand-
driven, (iv) evidence of industry involvement, and (v) availability of qualified teachers. The Project 
will upgrade and rehabilitate school and dormitory facilities, including repair of heating systems and 
floor and roof structures, improving sanitation and electrical systems, and provision of facilities for 
disabled  students.  The  Project  will  provide  the  institutions  with  furniture,  teaching  aids,  and 
10 classroom computers (each with software applications to support teaching and learning). The 
selection of training equipment will be based on training programs to be conducted at the four 
model schools. Market surveys will be carried out to determine dynamic economic subsectors that 
offer high employment opportunities for graduates as skilled labor. 
 
C.  Special Features 
50.  By  establishing  a  national  12-year  curriculum  framework  with  consistent  education 
standards and reforming the VTE system to become demand-driven, the Project will assist MECS 
in completing the transition of Mongolia’s education system from the Soviet model to a system that 
is consistent with internationally accepted requirements of a market-based economy. Through 
improving learning environments in rural areas, where poverty is prevalent, the attendance and 
completion rate of poor students will be increased. Only schools that have at least 30% of enrolled 
students from poor families will be selected for rehabilitation under the Project to ensure that poor 
communities will benefit from improved learning environments. 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      
51.  Model schools with a child-friendly learning environment and access to safe water and 
sanitation will demonstrate modern learning environments, student-centered teaching methods, 
integration of disabled students, school-based curriculum development, and school-based teacher 
professional development. The introduction of uniform transparent student learning assessments—
aligned to education standards—will enable the Government to monitor quality improvements of 
the education system. To further improve effectiveness and efficiency in the education sector, ADB 
will provide TA to support MECS in improving donor coordination towards gradually establishing a 
SWAp in education. The new Education Master Plan will provide the policy structure to improve 
coordination in the sector. The TA will include support in strengthening the financial management 
structure as a precondition for developing a SWAp.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
72.  Project  Beneficiaries.  Direct  beneficiaries  of  the  establishment  of  a  new  curriculum 
framework and the modernization of the education system will be all students enrolled in primary 
and secondary schools. Nationwide, about 560,000 students will benefit from improved curriculum, 
well-defined education standards, and enhanced assessment systems. About 31,000 students and 
1,200 teachers will benefit from rehabilitated school and dormitory facilities in 45 schools. About 
23,000  students  and  900  teachers  of  30  model  schools  will  benefit  from  upgraded  teaching 
facilities. About 21,400 teachers throughout the country will benefit from in-service teacher training 
programs. About 21,900 students of vocational education intuitions will benefit from the reform of 
the VTE system and a new demand-driven curriculum, which will improve their employment and 
income-earning opportunities after graduation. Student and teachers of four key VTE institutions 
will benefit from rehabilitated facilities and modern training equipment. Industries will benefit from 
improvements in relevance and quality of VTE. Graduates of VTE institutions entering the labor 
force will possess knowledge and skills that are in line with industry requirements, contribute to 
higher labor productivity, and increase economic growth. 
 
73.  Poverty  Reduction  and  Social  Development  Impact.  The  Project  will  have  a  direct 
beneficial impact on about 201,000 poor students in primary and secondary schools.23 Specific pro-
poor and social development measures of the Project include the following: (i) targeted school for 
rehabilitation  should  have  at  least  30%  of  enrolled  students  coming  from  poor  families; 
(ii) enhanced access for disabled children to general secondary education; and (iii) community 
involvement in school rehabilitation and maintenance. Over 90% of teachers are female, and the 
Project  will  directly  benefit  all  teachers  through  its  training  programs,  which  are  expected  to 
enhance the attractiveness of the teaching profession. To improve gender responsiveness, the 
Project  will  develop  strategies  to  address  gender  stereotypes  in  curriculum  and  textbook 
development. The Project was designed through a participatory process. During implementation, 
the Project will maintain broad stakeholder participation in its activities and benefit from improved 
donor coordination. The summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 13.

74.  Educational Benefits. The close link between educational development and reduction in 
the incidence of poverty, improvement of productivity, economic growth, and improving general 
living conditions is well established. The Project focuses on quality improvements of the national 
education  system  to  complete  the  transition  of  Mongolia’s  education  system  and  improve 
enrollment and retention rates, including (i) improved teaching and learning environments through 
a modern and relevant curriculum, student-centered teaching methods, rehabilitated and upgraded 
school and dormitory facilities, and modern teaching equipment and materials; (ii) improved criteria 
for assessing students through the integration of education standards with the proposed national 
curriculum framework; (iii) a uniform national system for accreditation of teacher training and 
certification; and (iv) reforming the VTE system to become demand-driven, leading to improved 
income-earning and employment opportunities for young graduates. In addressing early childhood 
requirements in curriculum reform, the Project will have an impact on the level of efficiency of the 
primary school cycle and reduce dropout rates.24  
 
75.  Financial Benefits and Sustainability. The most significant economic benefit will come 
from  increases  in  future  earnings  of  school  graduates  with  better  education  attainment 
(Supplementary Appendix B). Capacity building assistance provided through the TA—in supporting 
MECS  in  areas  related  to  financial  analysis  and  preparing  annual  and  longer-term  budget 
frameworks  linked  to  the  Education  Master  Plan—will  contribute  to  improve  efficiency  and 
effectiveness in the delivery of education services and reduce transaction costs.  
 
76.  Public expenditure on education as a share of GDP is estimated to average 6.5% in the 
period 2006–2008.25 It can be assumed that the budget will be sufficient to continue education 
service delivery at the current rate and finance the modernization of the system. By rehabilitating 
school facilities, particularly improving heating systems and insulation, the Project is expected to 
contribute to significant reductions in O&M costs. The Government share in the Project is included 
in the budget. Based on a projection of education expenditure, it can be assumed that the Project 
is financially sustainable (Appendix 4 and Supplementary Appendix B). 
 
77.  Environmental and Social Safeguards. The Project will carry out minor rehabilitation and 
repairs of existing school buildings and facilities with no land acquisition required, and no negative 
environmental or resettlement impact. Some school rehabilitation works will include improved water 
supply and sanitation and sewage systems, which will promote good health and have a positive 
environmental impact. There are no issues of ethnic minority language of instruction in Mongolia, 
therefore the Policy on Indigenous Peoples  is not applicable. 
 
78.  Assumptions. Successful implementation of the Project assumes that the Government will 
(i) maintain the high level of budget allocation for the education sector, (ii) be committed to improve 
donor coordination to strengthen the effectiveness and efficiency of the delivery of education 
services, (iii) maintain its commitment to carry out education reforms (including national curriculum 
reform), (iv) provide adequate budget to provide in-service training for all teachers employed by the 
system, and (v) reform and rationalize the current VTE system. To achieve its impact, the Project 
assumes that further steady economic growth will create new job opportunities. 
 
79.  Risks. At present, MECS’ managerial and technical capacity is limited, and might affect the 
smooth  implementation  of  the  extension  of  the  school  system  to  a  12-year  system  and  the 
introduction of the new curriculum framework nationwide. These risks will be mitigated through 
training  and  capacity  building  under  the  Project  and  associated  TA.  The  policy  impact  of 
introducing new education standards and uniform assessments will be significant. Risks include

EDUCATION SECTOR DESCRIPTION 
 
1.  The Ministry of Education, Culture and Science (MECS) is the central administrative 
body that formulates national educational policy and sets the standards for each level of formal 
education.  The  Ministry  also  administers  general  provisions  on  education  matters,  teacher 
training, curriculum development, and state examination procedures, and is responsible for the 
accreditation of higher education institutions. The current structure of the formal education 
system is shown in Figure A2.1 while Table A2.1 provides a summary of basic institutional and 
enrollment indicators of the education sector in Mongolia over the past 5 years. Education 
sector financing is described in detail in Appendix 4. The Government’s education policy has 
been driven by the Education Sector Strategy (ESS) 2000–2005. Its major focus has been on 
improvements in access to, and quality and relevance of, basic education services. However, 
prioritized implementation strategies were lacking. Building on the achievements and lessons 
learned  from  the  ESS  2000–2005,  and  based  on  a  comprehensive  sector  review,  a  new 
Education Master Plan for 2006–2015 is being developed with the assistance of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). 
 
2.  The formal education system in Mongolia consists of kindergarten and preschool (up to 
age 7), primary education (4 years), lower secondary education (4 years), and upper secondary 
education (2 years). From the 2005–2006 school year, the Government will extend the structure 
of school education from grades 1–10 (4+4+2) to grades 1–11 (5+4+2), with the expectation of 
having  a  12-year  system  (6+3+3)  in  2008. Basic  education  (primary  and  lower  secondary 
education)  is  compulsory  and  funded  by  the  state.  In  2004–2005,  557,346  students  were 
enrolled in 710 primary and secondary schools with a total of 21,458 teachers. In addition, 
MECS administers 43 higher education institutions and 42 vocational and technical education 
(VTE)  institutions.  VTE  institutions  consist  of  22  vocational  education  and  training  centers 
(VETCs)/vocational training and production centers (VTPCs) that offer a 2.5-year combined 
professional  and  general  education  based  on  the  former  Soviet  system,  which  leads  to  a 
professional  certificate  and  a  secondary  education  certificate;  and  14  branch  schools  and 
6 technical colleges that provide advanced training for higher-level skills development, leading 
to a professional diploma or bachelors degree. In 2004–2005, 21,911 students were enrolled in 
VETCs/VTPCs/branch schools. An assessment of the VTE system is provided in Appendix 7. 
 
3.  Higher education has experienced the most rapid enrollment expansion of any level of 
education in Mongolia over the past 4 years. The number of higher education institutions has 
increased to 178 during the past 10 years, of which 135 are private. Enrollment in private higher 
education institutions has more than doubled over the past 4 years. It is estimated that 80% of 
secondary school graduates continue into postsecondary education. In 1994, the Government 
began requiring public higher education institutions to begin charging tuition at levels sufficient 
to cover the entire cost of academic staff salaries, thus generating a large reduction in the 
government higher education budget. 
 
4.  The  strength  of  the  Mongolian  education  system  is  its  high  coverage  of  a  widely 
dispersed population. This is reflected in a gross enrollment rate of 98% among the school-age 
population and an adult literacy rate of 97%. Further, unlike most developing countries, girls are 
not disadvantaged in the educational system. In fact, 60% of all students enrolled in higher 
education in Mongolia are females. However, greater attention needs to be paid to address 
issues related to dropout rates. Table A2.1 reflects a decline in the dropout rate across the 
entire Mongolian education system, yet there are continuing concerns about the accuracy of 
official statistics. In a recent study of school dropouts in Mongolia, numbers of out of school 
children provided by different agencies ranged from 11,953 (MECS) to 68,115 (National Human

Rights Commission of Mongolia). The study revealed that migrant children were more than 
three times more likely to be out of school than long-term resident children.26 
 
5.  Key issues in the current Mongolian education system are (i) poor quality and relevance 
of  the  current  curriculum  for  primary  and  secondary  education,  (ii)  inadequate  teaching 
qualifications  and  skills,  (iii)  weak  learning  and  teaching  environments  in  schools,  and 
(iv) supply-driven irrelevant vocational education for youth. Despite progress in revising the 
curriculum and syllabi, the basic education curriculum remains overloaded with subject and 
content requirements, with insufficient emphasis on student-centered learning. The Government 
has decided to extend the current organizational structure of school education from a 10-year 
system to a 12-year system in 2008, which will require reform of the curriculum framework and 
development  of  new  education  standards  linked  to  the  curriculum.  At  present,  student 
examinations have little transparency due to lack of clear standards. Exams are not prepared 
according to uniform national standards or comparable between schools, which makes it difficult 
to monitor quality. Lack of a comprehensive teacher in-service training system and a uniform 
national teacher accreditation system are key constraints on improving the quality of education. 
Teachers graduate from universities and colleges with different levels of education. Teaching 
techniques and subject knowledge of many teachers are inadequate and outdated and need to 
be upgraded. In addition, the extension of the schooling period by 2 years will place new 
demands on teachers’ skills and competencies. 
 
6.  A major constraint in increasing enrolment and retention and in improving the quality of 
education services is the limited capacity of school facilities, which continues to deteriorate. This 
has been particularly acute in rural areas, where budget funds for preventive maintenance and 
technical resources for rehabilitation are scarce. Building construction and technology are based 
on  30-year  old  construction  standards,  which  are  inefficient  in  terms  of  use  of  materials, 
structural capacity, and energy performance. 
 
7.  Currently, the harmonization level of donor activities in the education sector is very low. 
Donor-funded projects are not linked to the overall policy framework and are managed largely 
on an individual basis. The low coordination level results in ineffective and inefficient use of 
scarce resources in the education sector. The new Education Master Plan will provide the 
necessary policy for improved coordination, effectiveness, and efficiency in the sector. Policy 
objectives established under the master plan will need to be prioritized and translated into 
operational  implementation  strategies  and  annual  budget  plans.  However,  due  to  MECS 
capacity limitations, an effective planning structure is not in place. Strategic planning, policy 
analysis, and evaluative research need to be strengthened to enhance planning and budgeting.

1.  Situational Analysis of School Physical Facilities. In 2005, Mongolia had a total of 
710  public  primary  and  secondary  schools,  with  facilities  provision  in  the  order  of 
896 school  buildings  and  144  dormitories  distributed  throughout  the  6  khoros 
(municipalities) of Ulaanbaatar, 21 aimags (provinces), and 329 soums (districts). Many

severe weather conditions, continuous use, and inadequate maintenance. About 499 or 56% of 
the school buildings are considered by the Ministry of Education, Culture and Science (MECS) 
to be in a very poor condition. Some 12% of secondary schools have not received any form of 
assistance for facilities improvement or replacement.  
 
2.  The  896  public  school  buildings  were  designed  to  accommodate  a  total  of  around 
325,000  students.  During  the  2004–05  school  year,  the  total  enrollment  in  primary  and 
secondary schools was 557,346 students—about 65% more than the planned capacity. Due to 
the increase in enrollments and lack of additional school space, about 43% of all secondary 
schools in the country were conducting classes on two or three shifts. The shift to the 12-year 
schooling  system,  as  planned,  will  exert  increased  pressure  on  the  capacity  of  facilities. 
Migration to cities has created overcrowding in urban schools and underutilization of rural 
school facilities. Some schools in Ulaanbaatar are operating at an average of 260% of their 
capacity with over 50 students in some classes. This has led to overuse of facilities and will 
result in the speedy deterioration of school facilities, if not maintained properly. In rural areas, 
migration has generated an underutilization problem of schools, with some operating at only one 
third of their capacity. 
 
3.  Inadequate budget allocation for preventive maintenance has resulted in considerable 
deterioration of school buildings and facilities over the last 15 years. Rehabilitation of school 
facilities has depended largely on donor support. The finance allocated for maintenance of 
school  facilities  has  been  inadequate.  Maintenance  is  only  2.4%,  as  a  proportion  of  the 
recurrent expenditure in the education sector. From 2000 to 2003, the Government’s provision

Financial data obtained from 44 sample schools rehabilitated under the Second Education 
Development Project (SEDP) showed actual expenditures on repairs and maintenance to be 
only MNT2,735,352 ($2,308) per school in 2002 (prior to rehabilitation) and MNT2,194,230

for repairs and maintenance should be at least $3,766 to $4,000 per year per building or $673

school budget expenditure items are reverted back to the national consolidated revenue—
leaves no flexibility for schools to utilize savings from other budget allocations for urgently

be allowed to retain the level of their budget allocation for the following year similar to the 
previous year without penalty. A number of schools have been piloted with this reform from 
1 July 2005.

VOCATIONAL AND TECHNICAL EDUCATION 
 
1.  The sole public provider of vocational and technical education (VTE) for youth is the 
Ministry of  Education, Culture and Science (MECS). Vocational and technical training and 
retraining for adults is offered by institutions under the Ministry of Labor and Social Welfare 
(MLSW), other line ministries, and the private sector. Overall, the VTE system is supply-driven, 
fragmented,  and  poorly  coordinated.  Industry  involvement  is  weak,  hence  the  majority  of 
programs are not relevant and do not respond to the needs of industry. 
 
A.  Formal VTE System under MECS 
 
2.  The provision of VTE for youth is the responsibility of MECS. The VTE system caters to 
youths who have at least completed grade 8 or are about 15 years of age. Most students 
enrolled in VTE institutions are from lower-middle income families or families below the poverty 
line. MECS administers a total of 42 VTE institutions. There are 22 vocational education and 
training centers (VETCs)/vocational training and production centers (VTPCs), which offer a 2.5-
year school-based vocational education that combines professional and general education, 
leading  to  a  professional  and  secondary  education  certificate.  School-based  vocational 
education  started  in  1965  on  a  50:50  theory-practice  ratio  that  includes  30–35%  general 
education, 5–20% basic vocational theory, and 50–55% practice, which is not carried out at 
present because of lack of appropriate training equipment. Curriculum model standards are 
prepared by MECS, subject to approval by the Mongolian Agency for Standardization and 
Metrology.  However,  the  vast  majority  of  graduates  from  the  combined  general-vocational 
education  system  cannot  compete  with  the  academic  performance  of  graduates  from  the 
general secondary education stream and do not find jobs in industry due to lack of employable 
skills. In addition, the social status of vocational education is very low, as the majority of 
students are weak performers in the basic education grades and come from poor families.  
 
3.  MECS also administers 14 branch schools (or schools attached to higher education 
institutions) and 6 technical colleges, which provide technical education for higher-level skills 
development, leading to a professional diploma or bachelors degree. Technical education is a 2-
year advanced training after completion of grade 10. This system started in 1996 by shifting 
from the 1-year specialized vocational education program to the 2-year advanced training, 
leading to a professional diploma. The diploma program can be linked with higher education 
after 2 years, leading to a bachelors degree. The aim of vocational education is to provide basic 
occupational  skills  and  knowledge  in  a  chosen  vocation  while  the  objective  of  technical 
education is to develop higher-level skills in a range of occupations and jobs in a given industrial 
sector. 
 
4.  The number of VTE institutions has increased from 36 in 2001 to 42 in 2005. VTE 
students as a proportion of all students in grades 1–10 declined from 11% in 1987 to 4% in 
2004. However, enrollment in VTE institutions increased from 12,177 in 2000 to 21,911 in 2004, 
of which 49.5% were female. About 144 vocational and technical courses are offered by VTE 
institutions. A total of 117 courses deal with basic training or professional certificate courses in 
occupations such as cooking and bakery, food production, café and restaurant services, sewing, 
beauty  culture,  carpentry  and  wood  processing,  secretarial,  farming,  painting,  consumer 
electronics, shoe repair, photo studio operator, and hotel and restaurant services. Most of the 
courses were designed without any labor market survey or active participation by industry. 
 
5.  Some  27  courses  are  offered  as  areas  of  specialization in  the  technical  education 
program—related to auto mechanics, computer technicians, heavy equipment operation and

10.  One  serious  issue  in  VTE  is  the  need  to  rehabilitate  and  modernize  facilities  and

seriously deteriorated (including heating, electricity, and water and sanitation systems). Old and 
inefficient building construction and heating technology generate high utility costs. The lack of 
appropriate equipment, adequate teaching aids, and learning materials constrains applying 
modern teaching methodologies. The quality of hands-on skills training is seriously hampered 
by outdated training equipment, and lack of consumables and tools.

D.  Quality of Teaching and Delivery 
 
11.  There were 1,160 teachers and trainers employed in the 42 VTE institutions in 2004, of 
which about 63% are female. The teacher-student ratio was 1:19, which is considered an ideal 
size. About one third of teachers in service are general education teachers. Most of the teachers 
have  bachelors  degree  and  about  1–5  years’  experience,  which  is  indicatively  short.  The 
pedagogical and technical skills and knowledge of many teachers are outdated and need to be 
upgraded. There is a lack of pre-service and in-service teacher education programs for technical 
VTE  teachers.  The  delivery  of  training  is  conventional  and  classroom-based,  with  little 
opportunity to develop practical skills due to lack of up-to-date equipment and training supplies. 
There is an acute shortage of learning resources. Most of the textbooks and resource materials 
are seriously outdated, with no systematic library management system in place. There are no 
multimedia facilities or even classroom computers available to apply modern teaching and 
learning methods. 
 
12.  Currently, there is no comprehensive recognized national system for skills standards in 
place. The quality of skills training depends on the quality of instruction, which is often adversely 
affected by the lack of training materials and equipment, and poor teaching environment and 
outdated knowledge of teachers. VTE institutions set their own examination, without formal 
external quality control or moderation. The industry is only involved occasionally. 
 
E.  Market  Orientation  and  Cooperation  to  Strengthen  Relevance  and  Demand 
Orientation 
 
13.  MECS’ VTE system is suffering from weak interaction with industry, poor coordination 
with MLSW and other training providers, and lack of an elaborate labor market assessment 
strategy to design programs of economic and social relevance. VTE is largely supply-driven and 
not significantly refocused to reflect the emerging needs of the labor market. The current labor 
market information system is unable to provide up-to-date labor market data to guide the design 
and revision of training programs. The lack of information and resource sharing among MECS, 
industry, and other training providers lowers the quality and relevance of training programs. 
MECS needs to improve strategies to explore ways to involve industry participation.  
 
14.  A  review  of  courses  offered  under  MECS  and  MLSW  will  be  necessary  to  clearly 
delineate  and  calibrate  the  type  and  level  of  courses  offered  by  each  ministry  to  avoid 
duplication of resources and redundancy of programs. Moreover, there is a need to cluster 
courses  into  major  occupational  groups  to  warrant  international  classification  of  training, 
facilitate  standard  setting  and  international  benchmarking,  and  for  economy  of  scale  in 
equipment provision and maintenance.  
 
15.  The present curricula have not been seriously updated in the past and need major 
redesigning to conform to the new national curriculum framework. There are only 16 training 
standards, which were developed from 1998 to date for sewers and tailors of soft items; food 
production, cooks and bakers; electric and gas welders; carpenters; plumbers and welders; 
mechanics  and  drivers;  shoemakers;  farmers;  hairdressers  and  beauticians;  construction 
masonry workers; general vocation in mining, repair and maintenance of mining equipment and  
drivers  of  heavy  load  machinery.  These  training  standards  appear  too  basic  and  almost 
duplicate the short-term courses at VTCs. There is a need to recalibrate these standards and 
introduce new ones for multiskilled development rather than simple operation work. Some 
constraints are the lack of an elaborate labor market survey and tracer studies, as well as the 
capacity and resources to undertake curriculum revision.

F.   Reform Needs 
 
16.  There is a need to develop a comprehensive national policy linked to a national human 
resource development plan and the present and future labor market. The current VTE system 
under MECS needs to be reformed, particularly addressing challenges related to (i) adjusting 
VTE programs to the reformed national curriculum framework and the extended grade 1–12 
school  structure  (including  amending  student  entry  levels  and  qualification  requirements); 
(ii) addressing challenges related to the revision of the current 2.5-year combined professional 
and general education program; (iii) developing new profiles for VETCs/VTPCs, focusing on the 
provision  of  relevant  demand-driven  vocational  education  programs  for  skilled  labor;  (iv) 
developing a demand-driven curriculum in close cooperation with industry, based on market 
surveys and internationally accepted standards; (v) assessing training needs for vocational 
teachers and developing an in-service teacher training system; and (vi) reviewing diploma and 
bachelors programs to improve demand orientation.34 
 
17.  A reformed VTE system needs to be in line with policies, regulations, and standards of 
all training providers to strengthen the efficiency and effectiveness of the entire system. A 
national  policy  framework  needs  to  (i)  streamline  legal,  regulatory,  and  institutional 
arrangements  for  the  subsector;  (ii)  define  the  roles  and  responsibilities  of  all  major 
stakeholders; (iii) agree on national skills standards; and (iv) prepare for a National Vocational 
Qualification (NVQ) system based on standards of competence set by industry.  
 
18.  Public-private partnership needs to be improved substantially. The private sector could 
play a greater role in developing, promoting, and owning VTE. Public-private partnership in VTE 
could build on the encouraging lessons learned from the Skills Training Voucher Program with 
support from the Employment Promotion Fund. However, incentives are necessary to enhance 
private sector participation in VTE provision.  
 
19.  The recurrent budget of a VTE school is based on enrollment. The variable cost of 
training has been calculated as one of the major parameters in allocating the budget. The 
present  system  of  public  budgeting  has  no  provision  for  recognizing  performance  as  an 
incentive for excellence. This is important to foster the quality of, and competition in, VTE 
provision. Another major drawback of the VTE system is the lack of financial autonomy. There is 
a need to initiate fiscal policy reform to improve the present financing mechanisms. 
 
20.  The quality assurance system in VTE is weak. The accreditation system for higher 
education  institutions  and  vocational  and  technical  training  centers  was  embodied  in  the 
Education Law, 1995, as amended. The Mongolian National Council for Education Accreditation 
was established in 1998 as the national accrediting body. To date, only two vocational training 
centers have been accredited out of 42 VTE institutions. An accreditation system should be 
developed  with  industry  participation  and  closely  coordinated  with  the  Mongolian  National 
Council  for  Education  Accreditation  to  enhance  the  present  accreditation  system.  A  NVQ 
framework does not exist in Mongolia.

caused overcrowding and high absenteeism in urban schools (nearly 7% of 8 year olds do not attend 
school).  High  migration  rates  can  be  associated  with  poor  student  performance  in  schools,  fees  for 
preschools and boarding facilities are prohibitive for aimag and soum households, the indirect cost of 
schooling in relation to household per capita expenditure increases significantly for grades 9 and 10, and 
poorer families are underrepresented in upper secondary education in both rural and urban areas. In effect, 
poverty is an important factor in determining whether a child is enrolled in school or not. Yet, without 
unhampered access to quality education, opportunities for earning a reasonable income and rising above the 
poverty line are restricted; indeed, graduates of at least secondary education are significantly less likely to be 
poor. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
The  main  institutional stakeholders  include  MECS,  aimag  authorities  (including  Education  and Culture 
Departments),  higher  education  institutions  (especially  those  with  an  education  department),  VTE 
institutions, primary and secondary schools, and kindergartens. The primary stakeholders are teachers and 
students. Through the Project, the structure and process of the professional development of teachers will be 
modernized and strengthened. The principal focus of the Project will be students in primary and secondary 
schools and VTE institutions. A number of international finance and technical assistance agencies and 
nongovernment organizations are also stakeholders in the education sector. A sector wide approach (SWAp) 
in education is currently being initiated by MECS, with Japan and ADB at the forefront. Other stakeholders 
include construction companies carrying out school rehabilitation of schools, and community groups who will 
supervise the rehabilitation process.  
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
The  Project was  designed  in  a  participatory  process  involving  major  government  and  nongovernment 
stakeholders  at  national  and  aimag  level,  school  directors  and  teachers,  community  leaders,  and 
development  partners  through  regular  consultations,  series  of  workshops,  and  presentations.  During 
implementation, the Project will maintain broad stakeholder participation in its activities and will benefit from

The Project will encourage (i) nationwide consultation in the development of the new national curriculum 
framework;  (ii)  greater  community  participation  in  supervising  and  ensuring  the  quality  of  (a)  school 
construction work and equipment procurement, and (b) school facilities maintenance; and (iii) partnership

D.  Gender Development 
 
Strategy to maximize impacts on gender: 
According to the ADB/World Bank Mongolia Country Gender Assessment (2005), girls enrolled in school 
outnumber boys in every aimag, including the capital. This pattern emerged in the immediate post-transition 
period and continues, although the gap has narrowed in recent years. Dropout rates for boys at secondary 
level are high among poor families in urban areas while, in rural areas, children drop out even at primary 
level. The reverse gender gap is particularly noticeable at higher levels of education. Women constituted 
80% of students who had completed secondary education in the United Nations Development Fund for 
Women (UNIFEM)-EGSPRS survey sample.   
 
To address the reverse gender gap in the school enrollment, the Project attempts to (i) incorporate learning 
materials that reinforce the right of all boys and girls to attend school so they can reach their full potential; (ii) 
examine the issue of gender stereotyping through analysis of curriculum content and identify strategies for 
improving portrayal of gender in curriculum content; (iii) provide training for teachers in techniques for dealing 
with presentation of gender roles and issues; (iv) give high priority to matching skills and educational 
achievements to employment opportunities through demand-driven vocational education; and (v) encourage 
parents to send their children back to school through the provision of improved school facilities, better 
curriculum standard, and more qualified teachers.
